step.context: \text{Let A and B be points on each of the lines} \\ \text{and let }\ora{d_1} \text{ and } \ora{d_2} \text{ be the direction vectors}\\ \text{of the two lines.}\\ \text{If the lines are coplaner, then what is}\\ \ora{AB}\cdot(\ora{d_1}\times \ora{d_2})?
step.reason: \text{If the lines are coplaner, then }\\ \ora{AB}, \ora{d_1} \text{ and } \ora{d_2} \text{ are in the same plane}. \\ \text{Therefore } (\ora{d_1} \times \ora{d_2})\text{ is $\perp$ to }\ora{AB}, \\ \text{hence } \ora{AB}\cdot(\ora{d_1}\times \ora{d_2})=0

step.context: \text{If }\dfrac{x-a+d}{\alpha-\delta}= \dfrac{y-a}{\alpha}=\dfrac{z-a-d}{\alpha+\delta} \\ \text{passes through A and }\\ \dfrac{x-b+c}{\beta-\gamma}= \dfrac{y-b}{\beta}=\dfrac{z-b-c}{\beta+\gamma} \\ \text{passes through B, and $\ora{d_1}$ and $\ora{d_2}=0$ } \\ \text{are direction vectors, what would prove that} \\ \text{the lines are coplanar?} \\
step.tex:
\text{The product } \ora{BA}\cdot(\ora{d_1}\times\ora{d_2})=0 \text{ given by} \\
\left\vert\begin{array}{ccc} \alpha-\delta-\beta+\gamma & \alpha-\beta & \alpha+\delta-\beta-\gamma \\ a-d & a & a+d \\ b-c & b & b+c \end{array}\right\vert
step.reason: \text{If }\dfrac{x-a+d}{\alpha-\delta}=\dfrac{y-a}{\alpha}= \dfrac{z-a-d}{\alpha+\delta} \\ \text{passes through A and }\\ \dfrac{x-b+c}{\beta-\gamma} =\dfrac{y-b}{\beta}=\dfrac{z-b-c}{\beta+\gamma} \\ \text{passes through B, then }\\ \begin{align} \ora{BA} &=\ora{A}-\ora{B} \\ &=\vector{(a-d-b+c)}{(a-b)}{}+ \\ &\qquad(a+d-b-c)\hat{\it k} \end{align} \\ \therefore \ora{BA}\cdot(\ora{d_1}\times\ora{d_2}) = \\ \left\vert\begin{array}{ccc} {\small (a-d-b+c)} & {\small (a-b)} & {\small (a+d-b-c)} \\ \alpha-\delta & \alpha & \alpha+\delta \\ \beta-\gamma & \beta & \beta + \gamma \end{array}\right\vert \\ \text{Expanding the determinant gives } \\ \ora{BA}\cdot(\ora{d_1}\times\ora{d_2}) = 0
